reviews.text: "DAWLISH RAILWAY"....... Again, this stretch of railway has been flooded.....What damage has been caused has yet to be determined.....A high tide, on shore 'Force 10' winds, soaked some of those people waiting + watching.....Well, float in some reinforced concrete pontoons, sink them off shore to dissapate the huge waves....Build a 'granite lagoon', whilst creating electricity, with turbines in the structure, again dissapating the force of the sea in these frequent high tide storms of the winter months.....Concrete  wave control, curved walls that redirect the waves back out to sea, which you can see at other locations around the world........Extending the railway, further out to sea will cost £300 million, which means the 'huge waves' will be closer + might even derail a train, creating a dangerous scenario for emergency services trying to secure the safety of passengers on the wave washed train......" DAWLISH RAILWAY"........Do you know who the constructor of this railway was + how many great structures he is famous for all around the U.K.?........Good Day To You Sir......

This lovely little stop on the Brunel designed coastal railway deserves a mention. 

A great deal of public money was spent relaying the track along this line which is one of the most scenic routes in England. 

This stop offers easy access to the town of Dawlish with its famous black swans and gardens.

At times of bad weather the train can be seen braving the spray from waves as it makes its way along the line here. 

Just up the track at the tunnel toward Teignmouth is a brilliantly executed Banksy like piece of wall art of a boy with a catapult.
